ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 9: I gave an "average" because we never ended up visiting the bottomland hardwoods. I really would have loved to see them.
awesome trip

I wish we had a seen a greater variety of forest types and ecosystems. I realize that loblolly pine is the cash crop down there, but I can only listen to people talk about how they manage for it so many times before its boring. It would have been cool to incorporate some other ecosystems into the tour and meet with more folks like Salem Saloom
Mike is an excellent teacher and great group leader. This trip would have been far less impact gun without him.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The interactions with a broad range of foresters, land managers, and landowners and the opportunity to experience forest operations concepts tangibly in the field. Incredible overall experience!
The people we visited! RMS was super interesting but also many of the other groups (that one urban forester guy with the goatbusters) - loved it!
it was the best organized field trip i've ever been on. Great balance of meetings with folks and time for ourselves to decompress and think about what we learned, and also to get to know one another.
I really enjoyed our day with the USFS and the prescribed burn. Our "cultural immersion" with BBQ, the civil rights museum, and skeet shooting was also great.
The course was extremely well organized. The instructor and TA did an incredible job of finding relevant site visits and covering material relevant and interesting to all students on the trip.
This field trip provided an in-depth understanding of Southern plantation forestry. There is no better way to learn about it than through this field trip.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: My only suggestion would be to work on incorporating some more walking through stands/woods/harvested areas instead of just driving to a new site and standing in a circle to talk about the surroundings. Obviously this is more of a logistical challenge, it was just a shame to not be walking through the woods more while we were in such fantastic environments.
Sometimes the days were just too long. It could be tiring at times.
bottomland hardwoods!
A forest ecologist needs to be included.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Great and must have add-on to Forest Ops.
great hands on understanding of how most of the land in the southeast is managed, and what the driving forces are that shape how it is managed.

As an ecologist, I was grateful for the opportunity to learn from this intensively applied-ecology system. These opportunities are a huge part of why I chose to do an MESc at Yale rather than a research university, and hope that this type of cross-disciplinary project is always possible. Thank you!!!

I'm an MEM interesting in working lands conservation. The material is only peripherally relevant to my work, but important nonetheless, as it will be critical for me to be able to communicate with individuals working in the industry on the ground.
I felt this was an integral part of my Master of Forestry program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Was recommended if you take forest ops and one of the "big forestry fieldtrips".
seemed like a great opportunity to go to the south and learn a thing or two.
An interest, but a lack of expertise and previous knowledge, in the subject matter.
This instructor Mike Ferrucci is excellent, and I wanted to broaden my knowledge of all types of American forestry.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
and then some
Absolutely
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Absolutely worth it if you don't have prior experience with industrial forest management. The course provides exposure to a completely different means of managing forests than is implemented here in the northeast, an important thing for anyone interested in the field of large scale land conservation, forest finance, green energy, sustainable investment, and any related realms.
Make sure you know who you will be visiting and with who you might want to network.
write up notes after each day of who you met with, what your thoughts were, etc. Is a great resource down the road.
If you're interested in forestry and timber operations at all, this is definitely a course worth taking, regardless of whether or not you are an MF.
This course is a great way to learn about the American South and to see a whole different world of forestry.
